MC: What does the `is` operator test in Python?

column3: Whether two names refer to the same object (identity)
Whether two values have the same contents (equality)
Whether two objects have the same type
Whether two objects print the same output

MC: What does the `==` operator test for most built-in types?

column3: Whether two names refer to the same object (identity)
Whether two objects have the same value (equality)
Whether two objects have the same memory address
Whether two objects were created on the same line

MC: Consider x = [1, 2] and y = [1, 2]. Which result is correct?

column3: x is y is True; x == y is False
x is y is True; x == y is True
x is y is False; x == y is True
x is y is False; x == y is False

MC: Consider a = [1, 2, 3] and b = a. Which result is correct?

column3: a is b is False; a == b is True
a is b is False; a == b is False
a is b is True; a == b is False
a is b is True; a == b is True

nums is alias is True

MC: What does the slice notation start:stop mean in a list slice?

column3: Include stop but exclude start
Include start and exclude stop

MC: Consider row = [0, 0]; grid = [row] * 3; grid[0][0] = 99. What is grid?
Which construction creates three independent inner lists?

column3: grid = [[0, 0] for _ in range(3)]

MC: Why can [inner] * n be a problem when inner is a list?

column3: It repeats references to the same inner list object
It creates n deep copies of the inner list
It sorts the list n times
It converts the list into a tuple

MC: What is the main difference between a list and a tuple?

column3: Lists can store only numbers; tuples can store any type
Lists are mutable; tuples are immutable
Tuples are faster for membership tests than sets
Lists cannot be nested; tuples can be nested

The assignment is ignored
Python raises a TypeError
Python converts the tuple to a list automatically

record becomes (ADA"
record becomes [ADA"

Values are automatically sorted numerically
Iteration order is random each time

MC: What is a primary purpose of a set?

column3: Store unique values (no duplicates)
Preserve insertion order of items
Allow indexing by position
Store key-value pairs

Lists are always empty
Lists are mutable and therefore unhashable
Lists contain only integers

MC: Consider nested = [[1, 2], [3, 4]]; shallow = nested[:]; shallow[0].append(999). Which statement is true?

column3: nested is changed because the inner list is shared
nested is unchanged because slicing makes a deep copy
shallow becomes None after append
nested becomes a tuple

MC: Which best describes a shallow copy of a nested list?

column3: Copies the outer list and also copies all inner lists
Copies the outer list but the inner lists remain shared
Copies only the first inner list
Converts the nested list to a set

MC: What does copy.deepcopy(nested) do for a nested list?

column3: It copies only the outer list
It copies only the last inner list
It recursively copies nested objects to make them independent
It sorts the nested list

MC: After nested = [[1, 2], [3, 4]]; deep = copy.deepcopy(nested); deep[0].append(999), which statement is true?

column3: nested changes because deep shares inner lists
nested becomes [[1, 2, 999], [3, 4]]
deep becomes identical to nested again
nested is unchanged because deep has independent inner lists

MC: A Path created as Path(demo.txt") refers to a file in which location?"

column3: The current working directory (unless a folder path is included)
The system root directory
The user's home directory only
The folder containing the Python executable

Creates the file and writes the text
Returns None and does nothing

column3: Returns an empty string
Creates the file automatically
Raises FileNotFoundError
Returns None

MC: In a notebook, what is the working directory"?"

column3: The last folder you opened in a web browser
The folder where Python stores installed packages
The folder where your operating system keeps temporary files
The folder Python treats as the current location for relative file names

MC: Which statement about dict.get(key, default) is correct?

column3: It returns default if the key is missing; without raising KeyError
It raises KeyError if the key is missing; even with a default

MC: Which statement about in with sets is correct?

column3: It checks whether a value is at a specific index
It tests membership efficiently (whether a value is present)
It sorts the set and returns the sorted values

MC: Which statement about tuple indexing is correct?

column3: Tuples cannot be indexed
Only positive indexes work for tuples
Tuple indexing works like list indexing; including negative indexes
Indexing a tuple always returns a list

MC: Which statement about rebinding vs mutation is correct?

column3: Rebinding changes an existing object in place
Mutation always creates a new object
Rebinding and mutation are the same thing in Python
Rebinding changes what a name refers to; mutation changes the contents of an object
